WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:13.583 --> 00:00:14.370
Hello.

3
00:00:14.370 --> 00:00:18.230
In this series of videos,
we're gonna be looking at HTML, CSS, and

4
00:00:18.230 --> 00:00:21.750
Bootstrap ,and here to tell us a little
bit more about what we can expect,

5
00:00:21.750 --> 00:00:23.640
here's Mr. Victor Moreno.

6
00:00:23.640 --> 00:00:24.920
>> Thank you, Mike.

7
00:00:24.920 --> 00:00:28.290
Basically, the series is aimed for anybody

8
00:00:28.290 --> 00:00:32.240
who wants to understand a little bit about
what HTML is and how to make websites.

9
00:00:32.240 --> 00:00:34.210
We talk about what websites even are.

10
00:00:34.210 --> 00:00:36.402
What your browser really
does behind the scenes.

11
00:00:36.402 --> 00:00:39.830
How to dig under the hood of your browser,
how to understand what's going on with

12
00:00:39.830 --> 00:00:44.550
HTML, how to apply CSS, how to manage
your files in a professional way, and

13
00:00:44.550 --> 00:00:49.000
how to use third party tools that make
your development process a lot easier.

14
00:00:49.000 --> 00:00:52.890
And if you look at my screen right now,
we can actually, by the end of the course,

15
00:00:52.890 --> 00:00:55.950
over a couple of episodes,
we actually make this website right here

16
00:00:55.950 --> 00:01:00.810
with a slider, some nice pictures,
some icons, a contact form.

17
00:01:00.810 --> 00:01:04.500
And we talk about how all of this works,
and what all of it does.

18
00:01:04.500 --> 00:01:09.217
So, hopefully, you stay tuned, and
hopefully you enjoy it and learn a lot.

19
00:01:09.217 --> 00:01:16.389
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Victor and Mike explain the basics of HTML and CSS. They go over how a browser requests and interprets a web page and how to use the browser to look under the hood of a web page. They also talk about tools like Bootstrap and Atom.
episodes.title: Introduction to HTML
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC].

2
00:00:13.801 --> 00:00:17.321
Hello, welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITPro TV.

3
00:00:17.321 --> 00:00:18.830
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:18.830 --> 00:00:22.640
And today we're doing HTML,
CSS, and Bootstrap.

5
00:00:22.640 --> 00:00:25.290
And with me today is our
subject matter expert Mr.

6
00:00:25.290 --> 00:00:28.490
Victor Moreno from
the Florida Vocational Institute.

7
00:00:28.490 --> 00:00:29.680
How you doing Victor?

8
00:00:29.680 --> 00:00:30.470
>> I'm doing great Mike.

9
00:00:30.470 --> 00:00:31.930
Thanks for having me.

10
00:00:31.930 --> 00:00:34.680
So we're gonna be talking,
as you said, about HTML, CSS and

11
00:00:34.680 --> 00:00:38.510
Bootstrap, so let's talk about
how the course is going to be.

12
00:00:38.510 --> 00:00:42.420
In short HTML is how you set up the
structure of webpages, CSS is how you set

13
00:00:42.420 --> 00:00:46.207
up the style and Bootstrap is like
a professional library with a bunch of

14
00:00:46.207 --> 00:00:49.830
pre-made CSS and JavaScript to
really speed up your development.

15
00:00:49.830 --> 00:00:53.661
And the reason we are including it here is
because we wanna take you from not just

16
00:00:53.661 --> 00:00:57.726
learning the basics but being able to put
something that looks very professional,

17
00:00:57.726 --> 00:00:59.550
looks real good, together.

18
00:00:59.550 --> 00:01:03.590
And we want you also speed up your
learning by using these tools and

19
00:01:03.590 --> 00:01:06.310
seeing how things are done
in a professional way.

20
00:01:06.310 --> 00:01:07.340
So today,

21
00:01:07.340 --> 00:01:11.750
in this particular episode, we're
gonna be explaining what a website is.

22
00:01:11.750 --> 00:01:14.600
So we're gonna be giving some
context to all the stuff that we're

23
00:01:14.600 --> 00:01:17.030
gonna be learning later on.

24
00:01:17.030 --> 00:01:21.160
We will also introduce you to the two main
tools that you're also gonna need to use

25
00:01:21.160 --> 00:01:22.910
to do any kind of web development.

26
00:01:22.910 --> 00:01:25.918
So that's your text editor is
gonna be your best friend.

27
00:01:25.918 --> 00:01:29.630
And looking under the hood of your
browser, that's not something

28
00:01:29.630 --> 00:01:32.520
that a lot of people have done,
looking on the hood of their browser.

29
00:01:32.520 --> 00:01:34.960
So let's talk about what a webpage is.

30
00:01:34.960 --> 00:01:40.850
If you look at my computer real quick for
a second.

31
00:01:40.850 --> 00:01:45.264
I already have the ITPro.TV
website loaded, but

32
00:01:45.264 --> 00:01:48.425
if I were to type here, itpro.tv.

33
00:01:48.425 --> 00:01:52.035
What I'm really doing is I'm
instructing my web browser to send

34
00:01:52.035 --> 00:01:54.235
an HTTP request to a server.

35
00:01:54.235 --> 00:01:58.655
And you IT guys know a lot better than me
how that happens, how it ends up with DNS,

36
00:01:58.655 --> 00:02:00.655
all this stuff, making it there.

37
00:02:00.655 --> 00:02:03.655
And I receive the response back,
but that's what I'm really doing.

38
00:02:03.655 --> 00:02:09.130
I'm just using software in a graphical
way to send a request to this web server.

39
00:02:09.130 --> 00:02:13.120
So, let's look under the hood
of the browser, right here.

40
00:02:13.120 --> 00:02:16.680
These errors are just some add-ons that I
have that I block a bunch of content, and

41
00:02:16.680 --> 00:02:17.240
this is how you block that.

42
00:02:17.240 --> 00:02:19.490
>> Now, how did you pull that up so
we could.

43
00:02:19.490 --> 00:02:20.020
>> Yeah.

44
00:02:20.020 --> 00:02:21.150
Thanks, good question.

45
00:02:21.150 --> 00:02:25.310
So, the easiest way to remember
is basically to right-click

46
00:02:25.310 --> 00:02:26.780
anywhere on the page.

47
00:02:26.780 --> 00:02:28.980
And then you can click on Inspect.

48
00:02:28.980 --> 00:02:32.460
Okay, so that'll bring up this panel
that has a bunch of tabs right here.

49
00:02:32.460 --> 00:02:36.480
And the way that I did it,
once you get used to it you hit F12.

50
00:02:36.480 --> 00:02:37.630
There's a command for Mac,

51
00:02:37.630 --> 00:02:43.210
I think it's Cmd-Option-I, but don't quote
me on that I'm not a hundred percent sure.

52
00:02:43.210 --> 00:02:46.010
But F12 is how you do it on PCs.

53
00:02:46.010 --> 00:02:48.230
So let's take a look at what happens.

54
00:02:48.230 --> 00:02:50.170
So look at when I typed itprotv,

55
00:02:50.170 --> 00:02:52.290
basically what happened is I
got all of this stuff back.

56
00:02:54.533 --> 00:02:59.690
All of this code, all of this source code
right here, that's what I got back and

57
00:02:59.690 --> 00:03:03.500
my browser's the one who basically reads
through all of that stuff, lays it out,

58
00:03:03.500 --> 00:03:05.780
figures out what it is,
figures out what images it needs to load,

59
00:03:05.780 --> 00:03:07.430
figures out what stashes it needs to load.

60
00:03:07.430 --> 00:03:09.180
All these things it
needs to do in order for

61
00:03:09.180 --> 00:03:12.240
me to have this nice,
awesome-looking website.

62
00:03:12.240 --> 00:03:15.190
And if we go to the Networking pane here,

63
00:03:15.190 --> 00:03:17.030
we can actually see
that process in action.

64
00:03:17.030 --> 00:03:19.400
So I'm just gonna hit Refresh here.

65
00:03:19.400 --> 00:03:26.770
And if I expand my whole
Developer Tools right here, look at

66
00:03:26.770 --> 00:03:31.710
all the stuff that actually happened
as a result of me typing itprotv.com.

67
00:03:31.710 --> 00:03:32.710
I'm hitting Enter.

68
00:03:32.710 --> 00:03:34.530
>> So
much more than a single request going out,

69
00:03:34.530 --> 00:03:36.430
there's actually a lot of things
going on in the background there.

70
00:03:36.430 --> 00:03:39.850
>> Exactly because what happens is, once
you get that response, that source code,

71
00:03:39.850 --> 00:03:41.500
this was the original request right?

72
00:03:41.500 --> 00:03:43.760
I get this response, this source code.

73
00:03:43.760 --> 00:03:45.940
>> This source code might
cause additional requests.

74
00:03:45.940 --> 00:03:50.010
So it might pull up a bunch of scripts, it
might pull up a bunch of CSS style sheets,

75
00:03:50.010 --> 00:03:51.070
a bunch of images.

76
00:03:51.070 --> 00:03:54.640
And each additional
asset that you request,

77
00:03:54.640 --> 00:03:56.750
it actually has to get
loaded individually.

78
00:03:56.750 --> 00:04:02.170
So as the browser goes line by line,
from top to bottom running the HTML,

79
00:04:02.170 --> 00:04:04.490
it might find an image
that it needs to load.

80
00:04:04.490 --> 00:04:06.230
So it goes and
sends a request for the image.

81
00:04:06.230 --> 00:04:09.230
It might find a style sheet that it needs
to load, it goes and sends the request for

82
00:04:09.230 --> 00:04:09.780
that style sheet.

83
00:04:09.780 --> 00:04:12.040
Maybe it finds a YouTube video
that it needs to load, so

84
00:04:12.040 --> 00:04:15.000
it sends the request to YouTube,
to load in that video.

85
00:04:15.000 --> 00:04:19.380
And as we can see right here,
this is a script, another script,

86
00:04:19.380 --> 00:04:22.710
JW player, a bunch of scripts.

87
00:04:22.710 --> 00:04:25.230
You guys got a lot of
coding going on here.

88
00:04:25.230 --> 00:04:30.010
>> We do [LAUGH].
>> We have a PNG image and so on.

89
00:04:30.010 --> 00:04:32.970
So this is basically what happens
when you're sending a request.

90
00:04:32.970 --> 00:04:35.884
You're really asking for a bunch of source
code and then you're your browser is

91
00:04:35.884 --> 00:04:38.550
looking through that source code
pulling up any additional resources.

92
00:04:38.550 --> 00:04:42.440
And once it has everything put together,
it does all this magic and

93
00:04:42.440 --> 00:04:44.940
puts this nice little layout for you.

94
00:04:44.940 --> 00:04:46.640
>> And normally pretty darn quick, too.

95
00:04:46.640 --> 00:04:48.012
>> Yeah yeah, absolutely.

96
00:04:48.012 --> 00:04:50.830
And as internet gets faster and
faster, this gets better and better.

97
00:04:50.830 --> 00:04:55.200
And furthermore, as developers get
savvier and savvier, they can find ways

98
00:04:55.200 --> 00:04:58.130
to package all the images in one,
package all their scripts in one so

99
00:04:58.130 --> 00:05:02.630
that If you have multiple programs
then you can only send one request.

100
00:05:02.630 --> 00:05:06.254
Because the developer did the job of
packaging them all into one you only need

101
00:05:06.254 --> 00:05:08.870
to fire one request,
get one response and it's fast.

102
00:05:08.870 --> 00:05:09.910
>> Very cool!

103
00:05:09.910 --> 00:05:16.350
>> So, the next thing that I wanted
to show you besides that network.

104
00:05:16.350 --> 00:05:20.844
Well if you actually click on any of these
requests you can see the request headers

105
00:05:20.844 --> 00:05:22.310
and the response itself.

106
00:05:22.310 --> 00:05:25.140
Well the response in this case was
a script so I don't see it there.

107
00:05:25.140 --> 00:05:27.040
But you can see details about here, so,

108
00:05:27.040 --> 00:05:30.460
next place I wanted to take
you to is the console.

109
00:05:30.460 --> 00:05:35.130
So the console is where you're going to
be able to see any errors that happen.

110
00:05:35.130 --> 00:05:37.110
Later on when you get into JavaScript,

111
00:05:37.110 --> 00:05:39.550
the console is going to be
your absolute best friend.

112
00:05:39.550 --> 00:05:42.030
For now, your console is going to be

113
00:05:42.030 --> 00:05:44.730
the main way that you realize
that something is not loading.

114
00:05:44.730 --> 00:05:48.110
So let's say that later on
were creating an HTML file,

115
00:05:48.110 --> 00:05:50.810
we create a link from that
HTML file to a style sheet.

116
00:05:50.810 --> 00:05:52.220
And we type out something.

117
00:05:52.220 --> 00:05:53.350
We did something wrong.

118
00:05:53.350 --> 00:05:55.450
In here is where that error
would come up telling you hey,

119
00:05:55.450 --> 00:05:57.940
I couldn't find that style sheet
you were telling me about.

120
00:05:57.940 --> 00:06:00.480
And then we would know to fix it.

121
00:06:00.480 --> 00:06:03.860
And the other place that I wanted to
take you to is the Elements pane.

122
00:06:03.860 --> 00:06:08.610
So the Elements pane is very important
when we're creating html layouts.

123
00:06:08.610 --> 00:06:12.480
Because, what it allows you to do is,
visually, you can inspect the page.

124
00:06:12.480 --> 00:06:14.620
So, let's say that I was editing this.

125
00:06:14.620 --> 00:06:17.880
This is a pretty complex page, but let's
say that there was a simpler page and

126
00:06:17.880 --> 00:06:20.300
I could, right-click here, Inspect.

127
00:06:20.300 --> 00:06:21.940
And it would take me
straight to that element.

128
00:06:21.940 --> 00:06:23.034
And by mousing over it,

129
00:06:23.034 --> 00:06:25.840
I can see the visual representation
right there on the page.

130
00:06:25.840 --> 00:06:31.106
So I can navigate which element is
which just by mousing over here.

131
00:06:31.106 --> 00:06:31.664
>> Very cool.

132
00:06:31.664 --> 00:06:35.288
>> So yeah, we're gonna be getting
into a lot more detail into that.

133
00:06:35.288 --> 00:06:36.888
This panel, on the right, right here.

134
00:06:36.888 --> 00:06:41.848
It's all about CSS and it's pretty complex
so we'll get into that when we get CSS.

135
00:06:41.848 --> 00:06:46.950
I don't want to bombard with stuff
here about the Developer Tools.

136
00:06:46.950 --> 00:06:50.250
>> Especially since a lot of
people haven't seen this before.

137
00:06:50.250 --> 00:06:54.782
What I want to do now is take

138
00:06:54.782 --> 00:06:59.336
you to atom.io, sorry.

139
00:06:59.336 --> 00:07:03.320
So atom.io, that is the other element,

140
00:07:03.320 --> 00:07:06.380
the other best friend that I had spoken
to you about, that's your text editor.

141
00:07:06.380 --> 00:07:09.400
So Atom is maintained by GitHub.

142
00:07:09.400 --> 00:07:13.650
GitHub is a very big and cool company.

143
00:07:13.650 --> 00:07:17.170
Everybody uses their main product,
which is a source control product.

144
00:07:17.170 --> 00:07:22.860
It basically used by coders to maintain
versions of their source code and

145
00:07:22.860 --> 00:07:26.900
control the deployment
of certain features.

146
00:07:26.900 --> 00:07:30.040
Control the incorporation
of certain features to

147
00:07:30.040 --> 00:07:31.140
what they call the main branch.

148
00:07:31.140 --> 00:07:35.350
So in short, it's used by developers
to collaborate with one another and

149
00:07:35.350 --> 00:07:37.430
they created this text editor, ATOM,

150
00:07:37.430 --> 00:07:40.470
which is like the cool kid on the block
right now, a lot of people are using it.

151
00:07:40.470 --> 00:07:43.520
>> I actually use it on my
MAC as my text editor for

152
00:07:43.520 --> 00:07:44.720
a lot of my show notes and stuff.

153
00:07:44.720 --> 00:07:46.290
>> Absolutely.
>> I love the color coding that it does.

154
00:07:46.290 --> 00:07:48.070
>> Yeah right,
the color coding is awesome,

155
00:07:48.070 --> 00:07:49.870
it does Markdown,
it comes with a bunch of stuff.

156
00:07:49.870 --> 00:07:51.270
That's a huge open source community.

157
00:07:51.270 --> 00:07:53.621
So there's a ton of add-ons for it.

158
00:07:53.621 --> 00:07:58.773
And if you want to install it as
a viewer you would go to atom.io.

159
00:07:58.773 --> 00:07:59.758
Click on Download.

160
00:07:59.758 --> 00:08:02.393
And one thing to know if
you're on a Windows machine,

161
00:08:02.393 --> 00:08:05.970
I personally use Windows so this is
a word of advice for Windows users.

162
00:08:05.970 --> 00:08:09.200
It installs to the one profile, so
it doesn't install machine-wide, and

163
00:08:09.200 --> 00:08:11.530
that's the main drawback
that it has I think.

164
00:08:11.530 --> 00:08:14.540
If you want something that installs
machine-wide because you want it for

165
00:08:14.540 --> 00:08:15.700
a lab setting or what-have-you.

166
00:08:15.700 --> 00:08:19.980
Like if you, for students or for
a computer that's gonna be shared between

167
00:08:19.980 --> 00:08:24.430
multiple people, there's another open
source set of software made by Adobe and

168
00:08:24.430 --> 00:08:25.640
it's called Brackets.

169
00:08:25.640 --> 00:08:30.170
So if you go to brackets.io, that's where
you can download that one and install it.

170
00:08:30.170 --> 00:08:31.600
And that one does run,

171
00:08:33.090 --> 00:08:36.450
that one does install through old
profiles on the the computer.

172
00:08:36.450 --> 00:08:42.242
So, right now, what I'd like to do is
just take you, show you, around an atom.

173
00:08:42.242 --> 00:08:45.098
And explain a little bit
about what's going on there.

174
00:08:45.098 --> 00:08:49.260
So the way that you normally work with
these modern text editors like Atom,

175
00:08:49.260 --> 00:08:53.689
Black Brackets and even Sublime texts is
another one that's very popular is you

176
00:08:53.689 --> 00:08:56.188
want open a folder with it, so you want.

177
00:08:56.188 --> 00:08:58.960
The text editor will have a little
file panel on the left and

178
00:08:58.960 --> 00:09:02.730
you want that file panel to be looking
at specific folder where all stuff for

179
00:09:02.730 --> 00:09:03.550
your website is gonna be.

180
00:09:03.550 --> 00:09:09.840
So I'm creating this new folder, and I'm
going to call it like first HTML lesson.

181
00:09:09.840 --> 00:09:12.920
Another thing for
naming convention folders,

182
00:09:12.920 --> 00:09:16.180
I think that you should stay away from
spaces and stay away from capitals.

183
00:09:16.180 --> 00:09:19.070
Because when you type URLs,
you type website addresses.

184
00:09:19.070 --> 00:09:22.090
That stuff is,
especially the path after the domain name,

185
00:09:22.090 --> 00:09:25.510
that stuff is gonna be case-sensitive for
the most part, in most cases.

186
00:09:25.510 --> 00:09:28.390
And you don't want to confuse
yourself having capital letters, and

187
00:09:28.390 --> 00:09:31.317
then if there's a space,
you have to type %20.

188
00:09:31.317 --> 00:09:32.130
It gets messy.
>> [LAUGH]

189
00:09:32.130 --> 00:09:33.420
>> So let's just not name anything

190
00:09:33.420 --> 00:09:33.990
with spaces.

191
00:09:33.990 --> 00:09:36.570
When it comes to web design, no spaces and

192
00:09:36.570 --> 00:09:39.700
try to stay away from capitals as far
as naming your files and folders go.

193
00:09:39.700 --> 00:09:44.210
So once I have that, if you have Atom
installed, you can right-click that and

194
00:09:44.210 --> 00:09:49.250
I also have Visual Studio Code, and
it's also another awesome text editor.

195
00:09:49.250 --> 00:09:52.310
But I'm going to open it with Atom and

196
00:09:52.310 --> 00:09:58.420
it's going to come up in a second and
here it shows me my folder and it's empty.

197
00:09:58.420 --> 00:10:04.553
So I can right click here and
create a new file and call it index.html.

198
00:10:04.553 --> 00:10:09.352
And the reason that we call it
index.html is because one of the most

199
00:10:09.352 --> 00:10:12.363
popular servers that's used is Apache.

200
00:10:12.363 --> 00:10:16.986
And Apache will, once you upload an
index.html to a folder in the Apache path,

201
